description: Probably borrowed from Dutch walrus, a compound of wal (“whale”) and ros (“horse”). Displaced native Old English horshwæl (literally “horse whale”). Compare similar constructions in Danish hvalros, Old Norse hrosshvalr, and German Walross.

nouns.description: walrus (plural walruses or walrus or walrusses or (both nonstandard, proscribed, uncommon and often humorous) walri or walrii)

entries.meaning: A large Arctic marine mammal related to seals and having long tusks, tough, wrinkled skin, and four flippers, Odobenus rosmarus.
(informal, sometimes derogatory) A man with a walrus moustache.
examples: You old walrus, don't you think it is time for you to lop your whiskers off?

verbs.description: walrus (third-person singular simple present walruses or walrusses, present participle walrusing or walrussing, simple past and past participle walrused or walrussed)

entries.meaning: To move dragging one's belly along the floor
To hang like a walrus's moustache
